description:
When the topic of accurate emulation or digital preservation comes up, higan is often mentioned. higan is an emulator that strives for accuracy above all else. It is widely regarded as the most accurate SNES emulator. 

It is also gaining support for other platforms of the era.
summary: One of the most impressive emulators out there

description: I have tested SNES, NES, and Gameboy games on Higan, and each has worked flawlessly. I also like that I can create keybindings for each platform. It could use a 'turbo button' option.
The best Super Nintendo emulator even better of Zsnes
ZSNES on windows 10 works fine on this machine,. I don't know what video and audio codec to use to get it to work. Help please
summary: I cant get this to work properly

description: Worked well for me. Emulates games well and supports XBOX wired controller.
summary: Works on Ubuntu 19.04 with Nvidia graphics driver

description: please update the emulator because there's a new release on the open source code
summary: great emulator but still out of update

description: Doesn't run any ROM faster than 12 fps. If your code was as clean as you claim, the emulator would work properly. This one is bloated garbage.

If you have problems with RetroArch (and you will have problems loading unverified ROMs on RetroArch), Higan is your second best bet. The U.I. is spartan but it works, it has different set of controllers for each console and it will run NES, SNES, Genesis as well as other classic consoles. However, it will not read Famicom Disk System (FCEUX does and I highly recommend that emulator as well). Remember to import the games first, and then load it.
summary: The Second Best All-Round Classic Console Emulator

description: Audio sucks, frame-rate unstable, and the app constantly crashes. The windows version is far superior.

I'd like to rate this higher, but i cant get it to work. currently trying to run on a Ubuntu 19.04 Virtaul machine with 1 processor and 2 cores with 4 GB or ram with host machine using a quad core i7. System Monitor in Ubuntu CPU Usage spikes to 100% as soon as i start up a snes game. 
Game runs at 13-21FPS for the SNES emulator. (only reason i downloaded it) Although outdated, ZSNES runs the games fine. issues with ZSNES interface had me look for alternatives, apparently there aren't any.
Works with most games of many platforms.
Ran once right after installing, played for an hour then exited. Now when I try to start it agian it crashes.

First, the people who have been reviewing need to understand what "accuracy" is on an emulator. It doesn't mean good performance, it means that the RNG and processing works as close to an snes as possible. Do you realize how hard it is to make a computer that has an entirely different processor "pretend" to be an entirely different computer, and do that and process everything? These games were intended to run on this single piece of hardware every single time. You're not running it on that hardware, other emulators get the amazing performance because they sacrifice the accuracy. To a casual playthrough this does not matter as much, but to a speedrunner or someone looking to do precise specific things this is very important. 

Do not expect good performance (atleast, just yet) without a beefy computer. If you want speed to play the game, get a different emulator. This emulator is doing exactly what it says, it even warns you about the high minimum requirements in the description. And to the people asking to update, do you understand how ubuntu works? Apps don't get updates unless it's critical, a security update, or the ubuntu team deems it necessary or reasonable. 

You only get updates on each release, if you want updates when the source code gets updates look for a rolling release distro such as OpenSUSE Tumbleweed, Manjaro, or Arch Linux. You get application updates every 9 months on Ubuntu, and quick patches in between these, and you only get these if you opt to upgrade releases. They are a bit more liberal about this process on interim releases (18.10, 19.04, 19.10) but are much more conservative about non-security updates on LTS releases (16.04, 18.04, 20.04). It is unlikely even if the developer or maintainer tries to push an update that the Ubuntu maintainers would even allow it to go through on your current release.
summary: Great emulator, read the review if wondering about updates or slowness

description: I have no idea how my PC with 16gbs of ram and an i5 8th gen runs this way worse than the emu on my PSP, which apparently is a port of bsnes, how did they do it?
it does not work audio and video are to bad
summary: audio and video are to bad

description: Extremely laggy, on modern quad core processor. Unusable.
i test snes, nes, genesis games. i'm very happy

Multi core is not supported, and isn't supported for most emulators. The emulator requires high clock speed to use, not core number. Other than that it's pretty much a perfect emulator, with seemingly 0 bugs.
summary: Requires high clock speed, otherwise perfect

description: Doesn't load any roms and issues with not having a bios file in respected emulation share file. Program launches but can't play games currently for 20.04 Ubuntu.
summary: Out of the box, doesn't work

description:
Used higan off on for about a year, bit buggy, some games don't play,etc.
Just downloaded RetroArch...yep, that's the program to download, works great
Works well for NES, SNES and GBA emulation and the was easy to set up
Tried running Earthbound on this and didn't run any faster than at least 14 fps. I am very disappointed on how this turned out.
I've used countless emulators over the years, this one just works. The config is simple, and all the NES games I've played so far have been flawless.
